On 7/15/05, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
>
> I suppose you cou=
ld use this technique (does it have a concise
> mathematical term?) to the =
input from a roving eye, thus removing the
> need for an ANN to drive the r=
otation of the eye itself. This does then
> mean that the eye is must analy=
se what it sees in isolation of what it
> just saw - e.g. normally it might=
 detect patterns larger than the eye
> itself by sweeping over an area, but=
 if we rotate the inputs then we
> break this kind of approach... unless we=
 inform the eye of what rotation
> it is currently in. Has any of the peopl=
e doing roving eye experiments
> used this approach of factoring out rotati=
onal invariance?

No, but it's on our to-do list. :)

Ken of course present=
ed a paper last year at GECCO applying the roving
eye technique to 9x9 Go, =
but his eye did not rotate.  We implemented
rotation into our eye for use i=
n identifying images with rotational
variance...that's what our paper at GE=
CCO this year was about.  But we
haven't applied it to board games, and wou=
ld very much like to.

It makes an awful lot of sense.

Derek
